abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Southern Jiangsu
            Environmental Protection Project is rated as unsatisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as negligible, Bank performance as unsatisfactory, and
            Borrower performance as unsatisfactory. The key lessons
            learned include: For large investment funds, the managerial,
            technical, and financial capacity of the administering
            agency need to be carefully assessed prior to project
            implementation. The industrial component of the project was
            designated at a time when much of Chinese industry was under
            direct government control and authorities were extremely
            reluctant to strictly enforce pollution discharge standards,
            let alone to shut down non-complying enterprises. This is no
            longer the case as the government has moved more toward the
            position of regulator than operator of industrial
            enterprises. Institution building as well as policy changes
            and studies are an inherent and cohesive part of most Bank
            financed projects. The Borrower needs to monitor the
            systematic and timely implementation of these activities.
            Realistic market assessments with the assistance of
            independent experts should be prepared for new products or
            expansion of production. Measures of project objectives
            should be included in the project itself to monitor their
            progress. Strong initial supervision with staff at earlier
            stages are vital to maintaining the momentum and motivation
            of the borrower.
